div1.p:
United States Consulate
at St Paul de Loanda
to the Department of State
Mr. Robert Scott Newton
Subject: Cotton Goods:
Abstract of Contents:
General information concerning Cotton Goods with full particulars as to Prices, qualities &c and Samples sent per Book Post
div1.note: (Copied for the Review of Statistics, Dec. 1880) Commpared with proof. Oct. 3/81

div1.p:
United States Consulate
St Paul de Loanda
14 September 1880
Sir
With reference to circular of March 19th marked Separate, I have the honor to say that the Yarns principally referred to are not imported into this Market.

The goods principally used in this trade are as follows, and I beg to submit the following information in reference to same as it may be useful to Merchants & Manufacturers anxious to cultivate this trade
Sample No 1

Grey Domestics. Portuguese name Algodões of good quality 30 yards long by 25 inches wide put up in Bales of 100 pcs, each piece weighing from 7 1/2 tts to 9 tts. To be doubled in 40 folds or laps. They generally have a good deal of Starch which makes them sell better.
Sample No 2

Striped Denims or Blue & White Stripes
Portuguese name Riscados Americanos Estreito
pieces 18 yards long by 25 inches wide, no red colours
Striped Denims Portuguese term Riscados Americanos largos:
pieces 18 yards long by 30 inches no Red colors
60 pieces per Bale. Weighing per piece 4 1/2 to 5tts
Sample No 3
Blue & White checks Portuguese name Riscados Chumbos or Maclussos
Length & width, selling prices, weight &c same as Striped Denims, both wide & narrow quality used. These generally come out a penny or so dearer than the stripes.
Sample No 4
Blue Raft Portuguese name Zuarte

pieces
pieces 18 yards in length by 40 inches wide. Weight per piece 7 to 8 1/2 tts, 100 pieces per Bale
Sample No 5
Fancy prints Portugese name Chitas
with clear ground and fast colors, 25 to 26 yards long, by 30 inches wide, 60 pcs per case
Weight per pce 5 tts
Sample No 6
Brilliantes Portuguese name Musselinas
Pieces 26 yards long & 30 inches wide, 100 pcs per case
Weight 4 3/4 tts per pce
Sample No 7
While Shirtings Portuguese name Morium or panno patente
prices 24 yards long, by 35 to 36 inches wide
Weight about 5 1/4 tts pr pce

All the above goods are sold in Loanda
retail
retail by the piece to the better class of natives.
A considerable quantity is also used up country in the Barter Trade for Coffee and Rubber although the following are the staple goods used in the Barter Trade.
In 1877 several pieces of goods of very good quality were brought in American Vessels as samples but they were unsaleable on account of the sizes being different.
The Cloth was good and if it had been put up in proper sizes would have sold well.
Sample No 8
Common Striped Denims, Portuguese name Riscados Americanos ordinarios
pieces of 16 to 17 yards long, & 23 to 24 inches wide. doubled in 18 folds or laps. 100 pieces per Bale
Sample No 9
Common Blue & White Checks. Portuguese name Rescados churnlos ordinarios
Price, length width &c same as above
Sample No 10
Common Blue Baft. Portuguese name Zuarte ordinario

16
16 yards long by 26 inches wide, 100 ps per bale to be doubled in 18 folds or laps.
Sample No 11
Satin Stripes, Portuguese name Puitados
pieces of 16 to 17 yards long by 25 inches wide
100 pcs per Bale, to be doubled in 18 folds or laps
Sample No 12
Chilloes Portueguese name Fazenda de Leia
15 to 17 yards long by 27 inches wide, 120 pieces per Bale. To be doubled in 17 folds or laps.

row.cell: Rs 1000 to 1050 or $1.08 cts to $1.14 cts

div1.p: Sample No 13
Striped Florentines. Portuguese name Riscados azues ordinarios
pieces of 16 to 17 yards long by 23 inches wide, 100 pcs per Bale, to be doubled in 18 folds or laps:

row.cell: Rs 1200 to 1500 or $1.30 cts to $1.63 cts

div1.p: All these should be well starched or sized much more so than the finer goods as they are all for the Barter Trade. There is great competition in this trade, so often they come a yard or so shorter, and an inch or so narrow, but all doubled to imitate goods of 18 yards which used to be the regulation length
Great attention should be paid to the regularity of the pieces in each Bale, and to the packing.

Many qualities of Handkerchiefs also are in use, ranging from 12 to 15 Handkerchiefs per price. However I do not send sample of these as the quality is so varied, and nearly all styles and qualities pass.
The duty on the above mentioned Cotton Goods is as follows:

85 Rs = 90 cts per Killo are Sample No 1
230 Rs = 25 " " " " " Nos 2/13
and 4% more on the value here, which is usually calculated at about 30% over the Invoice
Invoice price.

When these goods come via Lisbon or from Lisbon in a Portuguese vessel they pay 70% of the beforementioned duties. Manufactured in Portugal and bringing a Certificate to that effect they pay only 20% of the beforementioned duty.
Should they come in Foreign Vessels from any other Country they pay the full amount of duty as previously stated.
Shortly a new Tariff is to be brought into force which will increase the duty on Cotton goods considerably.
As soon as I can obtain a copy I will send it to the Department with a translation.

Nearly all cotton goods come from Liverpool and London in steamer to Lisbon and thence in the Portuguese steamers. At Lisbon they pay a small duty which allows them to pass here paying only 70% of the duty.
The expenses via Lisbon from England including carriage from Manchester to Liverpool Entry & Cartage, freight & by Steamers to Lisbon, & afterwards to this port.
Duty in Lisbon without commission is about 14% to 15%.

All
All these goods are used in the Province of Angola, but at Ambriz and the North the sizes vary, and the trade is different.
My information is taken from different Invoices received from by Mercantile Houses established here.
The Portuguese Steamers leave Lisbon on the 5th of every month for this port touching at the other Portuguese Colonies.
There are also two lines of Steamers from Liverpool, but it does not suit to ship Cotton Goods by these on account of the extra 30% duty the Consignees would have to pay.
Nearly all goods that come here are in execution of orders on account and risk of the Merchants here.
Consignments are not large although a well assorted establishment might do a good trade, as often the traders run short of different qualities in their assortments.

The usual Commissions are 5% for selling and 2% for remitting in Bills and 4% for remitting in produce. Some Houses however do the whole business for 5% commission without guarantee & 8% with
with guarantee.
It is difficult to give the number of pieces used during a year as no statistical statement of same is kept in the Custom House.
However I know of Houses here that use from 40 to 50,000 pieces in a year.
The trade is nearly all in the hands of the Portuguese, and it would be difficult to get orders from this market.
Lately travellers have been here from England and Germany to Solicit orders but have done little or nothing.
The Exchange is Rs 4500 per £1 sterling, or 920 Reis per Dollar.

I have the honor to be,
Your most obedient servant,
Robt S Newton
U.S. Vice Consul

To the
Assistant Secretary of State
Washington, D.C.
